questions.text: Which layer of the cerebral cortex is primarily responsible for receiving input sensory signals and sending them to other layers?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Layer IV

 

Explanation:
Layer IV is the primary input layer where sensory signals first enter the cortex. It processes these signals and then distributes them to other layers.


Cerebral Cortex Layers and Functions: Has six layers of neurons.

Layer

Function

I- Molecular layer

Receives nonspecific input signals from lower brain centers.
Control the excitability of stimulated areas.

II- External granular layer

Receives nonspecific input and sends axons to the opposite cortex through the corpus callosum.

III- External pyramidal layer

Sends axons to related cortical areas on the opposite side through the corpus callosum.

IV- Internal granular layer

The primary layer for receiving input sensory signals, which then spread to the surface and deeper layers.

V- Internal pyramidal layer

Sends large axons to distant nervous system parts like basal ganglia, brain stem, and spinal cord.
Controls signal transmission.

VI- Fusiform/ polymorphic layer

Sends axons to the thalamus.

Regulates excitability of incoming sensory signals.

questions.text: A patient presents to the clinic with difficulty feeling the precise location of a stimulus on their skin and reports problems distinguishing between different textures and shapes. Additionally, they are having trouble detecting rapid changes in vibrations. Which of the following somatosensory pathways is most likely affected in this patient, given their symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Dorsal Column-Medial Lemniscal System

 

Explanation:

The Dorsal Column-Medial Lemniscal System handles precise touch localization, texture, vibration, and proprioception. The patient’s difficulty with these sensations suggests an issue with this system.

 

Somatosensory pathways:

  • Two primary somatosensory pathways that transmit sensory signals from the body to the brain: the dorsal column-medial lemniscal system and the anterolateral system.

 

Pathway

Sensory Modalities

Dorsal Column-Medial Lemniscal System

(Option A)
  • Touch: Provides precise localization and fine gradations of intensity.
  • Vibration: Detects rapid changes in stimulus through phasic sensations.
  • Proprioception: Contributes to the sense of body position and movement.
  • Pressure: Allows for the perception of fine degrees of pressure intensity.

Anterolateral System

(Option B & C)
  • Lateral Spinothalamic Tract: Transmits sensations of pain and temperature (warmth and cold).
  • Anterior Spinothalamic Tract: Carries crude touch and pressure for general skin contact, along with tickle, itch, and sexual sensations.


Corticospinal Tract is involved in motor control, not sensory discrimination. (Option D)

questions.text: A 45 Y/o man presents with numbness and loss of proprioception in his right leg and lower torso. Upon examination, the physician notes a loss of vibration sense and two-point discrimination in the affected areas. MRI shows a lesion in the medulla. Which of the following nucleus is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Nucleus gracilis

 

Explanation:

Based on the above scenario, the patient is most likely having a lesion in the Nucleus gracilis

 

Dorsal column-medial lemniscal pathway:
 

Pathway

Sensory receptors → Spinal cord (dorsal roots) → Brain (somatosensory cortex)

Neurons

First-order neurons
  • Originate in mechanoreceptors, and enter spinal cord via dorsal roots
  • Pseudo-unipolar neurons with cell bodies in the dorsal root ganglion
  • Split into medial and lateral branches:
  • Medial branch: Travels up dorsal column to brain
  • Lateral branch: Synapses in dorsal horn, forming local reflexes, spinocerebellar tracts
  • Fibers from lower thoracic, sacral, and lumbar regions (T7-T12, L, S) ascend to medulla without synapsing, forming the fasciculus gracilis
  • Fibers from cervical and upper thoracic regions (C, T1-T6) ascend to medulla without synapsing, forming the fasciculus cuneatus

Second-order neurons
  • Synapse in dorsal medulla (cuneate nucleus for upper body, gracile nucleus for lower body)
  • Cross to opposite brain stem side, travel to thalamus (medial lemniscus)

Third-order neurons
  • Synapse in thalamus (ventrobasal complex)
  • Project to somatosensory cortex (postcentral gyrus, lateral parietal cortex)

 

Nucleus cuneatus: Transmits sensory information from the upper body (arms and upper torso). The patient's symptoms do not involve these areas. (Option A)

 

Ventral posterolateral nucleus (VPL): Located in the thalamus, not the medulla. This option is incorrect because the lesion is in the medulla. (Option C)


Nucleus ambiguus: Involved in motor control of the pharyngeal and laryngeal muscles. It is not related to the dorsal column pathway or the sensory symptoms described. (Option D)

questions.text: A patient presents with a loss of pain and temperature sensation on the left side of the body, below the level of a spinal cord lesion. Upon examination, the patient also exhibits impaired sensation of crude touch and itch on the same side but fine touch and proprioception sensations are intact . Which sensory pathway is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Anterolateral Pathway

 

Explanation:

Based on the above scenario, the patient most likely has a lesion in the anterolateral pathway.

.

Anterolateral Pathway

  • Transmits sensory signals such as pain, temperature, crude touch, itch, sexual sensations, and crude pressure from the opposite side of the body.
  • Damage results in loss of pain and temperature sensation on the opposite side below the lesion.
  • Characteristics: Slower transmission, less precise spatial localization, reduced ability to transmit rapidly changing signals.

 

Pathway:

Origin and Path
  • Sensory signals enter the spinal cord via dorsal roots; and originate from nociceptors, thermoreceptors, and mechanoreceptors.

First Order Neurons
  • Afferent fibers with cell bodies in dorsal root ganglia (DRG); terminate in the dorsal horn.

Second Order Neurons
  • Cell bodies in laminae I, II, and V of the dorsal horn; axons cross the midline and ascend in the anterolateral funiculus.
  • Synapses with VPL of the thalamus
  • Crude Touch Fibers -Form the anterior spinothalamic tract.
  • Pain and Temperature Fibers - Form the lateral spinothalamic tract.

Third Order Neurons
  • Originate from VPL, midline, and intralaminar nuclei of the thalamus; project to specific sensory cortex areas.

Termination Points
  • Reticular nuclei of the brainstem; Thalamus: Ventrobasal complex (tactile signals) and intralaminar nuclei (pain signals).

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the sensory and motor deficits in Brown-Séquard Syndrome?

choices.text: Contralateral loss of pain and temperature; ipsilateral loss of proprioception and vibration.
Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature; contralateral loss of proprioception and vibration.
Ipsilateral loss of all sensations at the lesion; contralateral motor loss below the lesion.
Contralateral loss of vibration and fine touch ; ipsilateral loss of temperature, and crude touch.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Contralateral loss of pain and temperature; ipsilateral loss of proprioception and vibration.

Explanation:

Spinal cord syndromes:

Condition

Description

Clinical Findings

Brown-Séquard Syndrome
  • Hemisection of the spinal cord.
  • Ipsilateral loss of all sensation at the level of the lesion; ipsilateral LMN signs (e.g., flaccid paralysis) at the level of the lesion;
  • Ipsilateral UMN signs below the level of lesion (due to corticospinal tract damage);
  • Ipsilateral loss of proprioception, vibration, and fine touch below the level of lesion (due to dorsal column damage);
  • Contralateral loss of pain, temperature, and crude touch below the level of lesion (due to spinothalamic tract damage);
  • If a lesion occurs above T1, it may present with ipsilateral Horner syndrome due to damage of the oculosympathetic pathway.

Anterior Spinal Artery Occlusion
  • Spinal cord infarction sparing dorsal horns and columns.
  • Watershed area mid-thoracic;
  • Artery of Adamkiewicz supplies ASA below T8.
  • Can follow aortic aneurysm repair.
  • Presents with UMN signs below lesion (corticospinal tract),
  • LMN signs at the level of lesion (anterior horn), and
  • Loss of pain and temperature sensation below the lesion (spinothalamic tract).

Tabes Dorsalis
  • Degeneration/demyelination of dorsal columns and roots caused by Treponema pallidum (tertiary syphilis).
  • Progressive sensory ataxia (impaired proprioception and poor coordination); Positive Romberg sign; Absent deep tendon reflexes (DTRs);
  • Seen in the terminal stage of syphilis
  • Associated with shooting pain, Argyll Robertson pupils, and Charcot joints.

Syringomyelia
  • A fluid-filled, gliosis-lined cavity within the spinal cord,
  • Often associated with Chiari I malformation.
  • “Cape-like” loss of pain and temperature sensation in bilateral upper extremities (due to damage of fibers crossing in anterior white commissure);
  • LMN deficits if anterior horns are affected;
  • Most lesions occur between C2 and T9.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding removal of each somatosensory area is correct?

choices.text: Somatosensory Area I: complete loss of pain and temperature sensations.
Somatosensory Area II: inability of precise localization of sensations
Somatosensory Association Areas: inability to recognize two sides of an object
Somatosensory Area I: enhance ability to judge the shape of an object

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Somatosensory Association Areas : inability to recognize two side of an object

 

Explanation:

 

Feature

Somatosensory Area I
(SSA 1)

Somatosensory Area II (SSA 2)

Somatosensory Association Area

Location

Postcentral gyrus (Brodmann's areas 3, 1, and 2).

Superior wall of Sylvian fissure

Brodmann's areas 5 and 7, located in parietal cortex behind SSA I

Representation and localisation
  • High localization of body parts.
  • Nose, lips, mouth and face laterally; head, neck, shoulder and lower body part medially
  • Poor localization (Option B)
  • Face is represented anteriorly, arms centrally and legs posteriorly

Combines information from the primary somatosensory area, leading to complex sensations, such as feeling an object like a knife or ball.

Function

Primary area for somatic sensation

Less known functions; Relies on input from SSA I

Decipher deeper meanings of sensory information from SSA

Sensory Information

Receive inputs from thalamic and cortical areas

Signals enter from brain stem, SSA I and from other sensory areas (visual and auditory)

Receives signals from SSA I, thalamus,visual cortex and auditory cortex

Effect of Excision

B/L excision of leads to:

  1. Loss of precise localization of sensations
  2. Inability to judge pressure against the body, weight, texture, or shape of the object (astereognosis) (Option D).
  3. Pain and temperature senses preserved but poorly localized (Option A)

Removal of parts of SSA II does not affect the response of neurons in SSA I

U/L removal leads to:

  1. Amorphosynthesis: Difficulty recognizing objects on one side. (Option C)
  2. Hemineglect: Denial of the existence of the opposite side of the body.
  3. Constructional apraxia: Difficulty in constructing a picture.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the representation in motor and sensory homunculus?

choices.text: Hand and digits have large cortical representation in the motor homunculus
Feet represented at the bottom of both the precentral gyrus and postcentral gyrus
Trunk and back have large cortical representation in both homunculi
Cortical representation is proportional to the size of the body part in both homunculi

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hand and digits have large cortical representation in both homunculi

 

Explanation:

Homunculus represents either the motor or the sensory distribution along the cerebral cortex of the brain.

 

Feature 

Motor Homunculus

Sensory Homunculus

Location 

Precentral gyrus

Postcentral gyrus

Representation 

Feet at the top of the gyrus (Option B); face at the bottom

Legs on top and head at the bottom of the gyrus (Option B)

Cortical Representation (Option D)

Proportionate to the skill involved in fine, voluntary activities

Proportional to the number of sensory receptors that sense muscle position and changes in muscle length

Large Representation Areas (Option C)

Hand, digits (Option A), lips, jaw, and tongue (areas involved in speech and hand movements) 

Face (especially lips), 

Hand (especially digits) (Option A)

Small Representation Areas

Trunk and lower limb

Trunk and lower limb

Specialization

Large area for lips, jaw, and tongue due to specialization in speech (vocalization of the cortex)
  • Large area for face mainly lips) due to speech
  • Large area for hand(mainly digits) due to cutaneous sensations from areas involved in skilled activities

Sensory Homunculus:

 

Motor Homunculus:

questions.text: A 45-year-old man recently had his right leg amputated below the knee. Weeks after surgery, he feels sensations and pain in the missing leg area, sometimes triggered by touching his thigh. Which statement best explains the patient's condition and suggests a treatment?

choices.text: Brain reorganization of cortical brain area & Spinal cord stimulation may help.
Infection at the amputation site causes pain & Antibiotics should be prescribed.
Reorganization at spinal cord neuronal connection leading to pain.
Pain is due to rejection of the prosthetic limb & Discontinue use immediately.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Brain reorganization of cortical brain area & Spinal cord stimulation may help.

 

Explanation:

 

Cortical plasticity

  • Refers to the ability of neurons to modify their connections under specific circumstances.
  • Cortical structures are capable of reorganization (plasticity) after loss of a body part, neighboring areas take over the cortical area of the lost part. (Option A).
  • Cortical connections of sensory units become weak with disuse and strengthen with use.

 

Phantom Limb Pain

  • Perceived due to cortical plasticity
  • In the phantom limb phenomenon, the limb actually does not exist (amputated), but the patient complains that he feels pain or itch in the limb
  • Based on the evidence, brain reorganization occurs when sensory input is cut off. For example: In leg amputees, the ventral posterior thalamic nucleus can perceive the signal that once received input from leg and foot now responds to stump (thigh) stimulation

 

Management :

  1. Epidural Anesthesia: Used during amputation surgery to reduce acute pain and subsequent need for opioids, lowering phantom pain incidence.
  2. Spinal Cord Stimulation: Electric current stimulates spinal pathways, reducing phantom limb pain and causing a tingling sensation instead in phantom limb (Option A)

questions.text: Which law explains the phenomenon of phantom limb pain?

choices.text: Muller's Doctrine of Specific Nerve Energy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Law of Projection

 

Explanation: The law of Projection forms the basis of phantom limb

 

Laws of Sensory Physiology

 

Bell-Magendie Law :

  • States that the dorsal root of the spinal cord is sensory and the ventral root of the spinal cord is motor in function. (Option B)

 

Muller's Doctrine of Specific Nerve Energy :

  • States that sensation evoked by a stimulus that generates impulse in the specific sensory pathway depends on the precise area of the brain that is eventually activated by the stimulus. (Option A)

 

Law of Projection :

  • States that no matter where a specific sensory pathway is stimulated along its course to the cortex, the sensation is referred to the location of the receptors.
  • Forms the basis of the phantom limb. (Option C)

 

Weber-Fechner Law :

  • States that the magnitude of sensation felt is proportionate to the logarithm of the intensity of the stimulus. (Option D)

Interpreted signal strength = Log (Stimulus) + Constant

  • Emphasizes that the greater the background sensory intensity, the greater an additional change must be for the individual to detect the change.

 

Labelled Line Theory

  • States that each sensory receptor is specialized to detect specific stimuli and sends signals via dedicated nerve fibers to the corresponding area of the somatosensory cortex.

questions.text: A 45 Y/o right-handed woman presents with difficulty in performing coordinated movements and a lack of fluidity in her actions, particularly when performing tasks that require the integration of both hands, such as typing or playing the piano. Which of the following brain regions is most likely implicated in her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Supplementary Motor Cortex

 

Explanation:

Based on the above scenario, the patient most likely has a lesion in the supplementary motor cortex, which is important for complex bimanual coordination.

 

Cortical Motor areas:

 

The motor cortex is located in the frontal lobe.

Primary Motor Cortex:

  • Corresponds to Brodmann Area 4
  • It lies in the first convolution of the frontal lobes anterior to the central sulcus
  • Responsible for executing voluntary movements and controlling fine motor skills (Option A)

Premotor Cortex:

  • Corresponds to Brodmann area 6
  • Lies 1-3 cm anterior to the primary motor area
  • Responsible for setting posture before movement (Option B)

Supplementary Motor Cortex:

  • Lies mainly in the longitudinal fissure
  • Responsible for Bimanual coordination (Option C)

Cortical Association Areas:

  • Commands for voluntary movements originate in cortical association areas (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following is the major contributor to the corticospinal tract in terms of percentage of descending fibers?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Somatosensory area

 

Explanation:

 

Corticospinal tract:

  • The corticospinal tract, also known as the pyramidal tract, is the most important descending tract from the motor cortex.
  • Contribution:
  • Primary motor cortex- 30% (Option A)
  • Premotor and supplementary cortex- 30% (Options B&C)
  • Somatosensory area- 40% (Option D)
  • After leaving the cortex, the tract passes through the posterior limb of the internal capsule, then through the brainstem and into the medulla.
  • In the medulla, most of the fibers cross to the opposite side, forming the medullary pyramids.
  • These crossed fibers descend as the lateral corticospinal tract finally terminates in the spinal cord.
  • Some fibers which do not cross to the opposite side in the medulla pass ipsilaterally down to the spinal cord as the ventral corticospinal tract.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding extrapyramidal tracts?

choices.text: The tectospinal tract functions through gamma motor neurons
Pontine and medullary reticulospinal tracts are excitatory and inhibitory, respectively
The rubrospinal tract is involved in the lateral motor pathway

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The tectospinal tract functions through gamma motor neurons

 

Explanation:

 

Extrapyramidal tracts:

  • These include the reticulospinal tract, vestibulospinal tract, tectospinal tract and rubrospinal tract.
  • All of them originate from the brain and terminate in the spinal cord. Hence, all are descending tracts (Option A)

 

Tract

Reticulospinal tract

Vestibulospinal tract

Tectospinal tract

Rubrospinal tract

Origin

Reticular activating system

Medial and inferior vestibular nuclei

Superior colliculus of the midbrain

Red nucleus

Characteristics

Two types:

Pontine (excitatory) and medullary (inhibitory) tracts (Option C)

 

They are involved in maintaining posture and modulating muscle tone via gamma motor neurons (Option B)

It controls antigravity muscles, such as proximal limb extensors, to control posture and balance

Controls head and eye movements

Controls distal limb muscles

The tract excites flexor motor neurons and inhibits extensor motor neurons

Motor pathway

Medial

Medial

Medial

Lateral (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following extra-pyramidal tracts contributes to the lateral motor pathway?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Rubrospinal tract

 

Explanation:

 

 

Lateral motor pathway

Medial motor pathway

Comprises of:
  • Corticospinal tract
  • Rubrospinal tract
  • Reticulospinal tract
  • Vestibulospinal tract
  • Tectospinal tract

Pathway and control
  • Terminates in the dorsolateral area of spinal gray matter and controls distal muscles
  • Terminates in ventromedial area of spinal gray matter and controls axial and proximal muscles

Function
  • Fine, skilled, voluntary motor movements
  • Maintaining erect posture

 

 

Vestibulospinal tract (Option A): This is part of the medial motor pathway, not lateral. It mainly helps maintain balance and posture by activating extensor muscles of the trunk and proximal limbs. It doesn’t contribute to fine motor control of the limbs.

Reticulospinal tract (Option C): Also a medial motor pathway. It regulates muscle tone, automatic postural adjustments, and basic locomotion. It influences trunk and proximal limb muscles rather than distal limbs.

Tectospinal tract (Option D): Another medial motor tract. It is involved in reflexive head and neck movements in response to visual or auditory stimuli. It has no role in controlling limb muscles or fine motor movement.

questions.text: A 60 y/o man presents with complaints of weakness and difficulty walking. Upon examination, he is found to have grade 1 power in right leg muscle and an exaggerated knee-jerk reflex. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Lower motor neuron lesion of the L4
Lesion of the Left internal capsule
Lesion of the right internal capsule

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Lesion of the left internal capsule

Explanation:

  • The internal capsule contains corticospinal tract fibers, and a lesion in this location will cause an upper motor neuron lesion.

Upper motor neurons (UMN):

  • Neurons in the cortex and brainstem that activate lower motor neurons.
  • The pyramidal tract and extrapyramidal tract are both considered UMNs because they both influence alpha motor neurons.
  • All neurons above the alpha motor neuron are upper motor neurons.

 

Lower motor neurons (LMN):

  • Spinal and cranial motor neurons that directly innervate skeletal muscles.
  • The alpha motor neuron is considered the lower motor neuron.
  • The lower motor neuron is the final common pathway for both upper motor neurons and the stretch reflex.
  • The corticospinal tract is excitatory to lower motor neurons while the extrapyramidal tract is inhibitory.

 

Feature

UMN Lesion

LMN Lesion

Atrophy

None

Severe (loss of trophic factor)

Fasciculation

None

Present

Tone

Hypertonia (spasticity & rigidity)

Hypotonia (Decreased)

Deep tendon reflex

Hyperactive

Hypoactive or absent

Muscle group affected

Regional

Segmental/distal

Babinski sign

Positive

Absent


An upper motor neuron lesion at the level of the L4 spinal nerve root would not affect the knee-jerk reflex. (Option B)

LMN of L4 will show hyporeflexia or areflexia not exagerrated knee jerk reflex ( Option A)

questions.text: A 65-year-old man complains of difficulty moving his arms and states that they feel "stiff." Upon examination, both arms show increased resistance to passive movement. The resistance is present throughout the range of motion and does not change with the speed of movement. What is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Lesion of the extrapyramidal tract

 

Explanation:

 

  • Rigidity is defined as an increased resistance to passive movement that is not velocity-dependent, meaning the resistance remains constant regardless of the speed of movement.
  • Rigidity is a feature of extrapyramidal lesions.

 

Feature

Spasticity

Rigidity

Definition

Velocity-dependent resistance

Velocity-independent resistance

Mechanism

Lesion of the pyramidal tract (Option C)

Lesion of the extrapyramidal tract

Clinical Finding

Resistance increases with speed

Resistance is continuous and does not vary with the speed of movement

Example

Clasp-knife spasticity

Lead pipe rigidity, cogwheel rigidity

Associated with

Weakness

Hypertonia

 

Lower motor neuron lesions are characterized by hypotonia (decreased muscle tone), muscle wasting (atrophy), weakened or absent reflexes, and flaccid paralysis. (Option A)


Cerebellar lesions can cause motor dysfunction, hypotonia, not rigidity. (Option B)

questions.text: A 17 y/o male is brought after being struck by a car. He is unconscious and exhibiting abnormal posturing. His arms are stiffly extended, his forearms are pronated, his wrists and fingers are flexed, and his legs are extended with his toes pointed inward. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Decerebrate rigidity

 

Explanation:

 

The patient's posturing is characteristic of decerebrate rigidity.

 

Feature

Decerebrate Rigidity

Decorticate Rigidity

Definition

A state of severe hypertonia characterized by extension of all four limbs.

A state in which the upper extremities are flexed and the lower extremities are extended.

Cause

Damage to the lower midbrain and upper pons

Damage to the upper midbrain

Mechanism

Loss of descending inhibition to the pontine reticular system causes overactivity of this system, which excites antigravity muscles.

Rubrospinal tract excitation of flexor muscles in the upper extremities results in flexion due to damage above the red nucleus.

Posture

Arms adducted and extended

Forearms pronated

Wrists and fingers flexed

Legs extended

Feet plantar flexed

Arms adducted and flexed

Wrists and fingers flexed

Legs extended

Plantar flexion of the feet

(Option A)

Clinical Significance

Severe brain stem damage; poor prognosis

Better prognosis than decerebrate rigidity

 

 

 

Cerebellar ataxia typically manifests as uncoordinated and inaccurate movements, often with intention tremor rather than the fixed, rigid posturing. (Option C)


Spinal shock can occur after spinal cord injury and presents as a flaccid paralysis with loss of reflexes below the level of the lesion. (Option D)
